title.children: 'Pretty terrifying': Advocates say medicine shortages still an issue, despite stockholding rules

image.altText: A luxury cruise on the ocean ship beneath a clear sky.

items.synopsis: MS Caledonian Sky was arrested off Roebuck Bay late last month over a separate dispute. Now an international union alleges its crew was underpaid.

title.children: Luxury cruise ship detained off WA now at centre of wage theft allegations

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe will give his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while Wall Street fell after economic data prompted concerns interest rates will stay higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Philip Lowe to give final speech as RBA governor, ASIC sues PayPal Australia, Wall Street falls on interest rate fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it yesterday, Australia's economy has slowed again, with data from the June quarter seeing growth of just 0.4%. Annually, the economy's growth rate was a slim 2.1%. It's also the second-straight quarter that GDP per person was in negative territory, meaning households are feeling the squeeze from the RBA's interest rate increases since last May. So what does a slowing economy mean for households, businesses and rates? Business reporter Nassim Khadem took a look — and you can watch it below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Australia's economy has slowed again as interest rates slash consumer spending

children.content: If you missed it yesterday,
Australia's economy has slowed again
, with data from the June quarter seeing growth of just 0.4%.
Annually, the economy's growth rate was a slim 2.1%.
It's also the second-straight quarter that GDP per person was in negative territory, meaning households are feeling the squeeze from the RBA's interest rate increases since last May.
So what does a slowing economy mean for households, businesses and rates?
Business reporter Nassim Khadem
took a look — and you can watch it below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PayPal Australia has issued a short statement in response to the legal action announced by ASIC this morning, saying they are been cooperating with the regulator and are reviewing the claims made. Earlier this morning, ASIC announced it was suing PayPal Australia over a contract term that gives small businesses just 60 days to dispute any fees they were charged, or they would be assumed to accept them. A spokesperson for PayPal Australia says the company is reviewing the allegations. "We have been working in full cooperation with ASIC and take this matter very seriously," they said. "It would not be appropriate to comment in detail on proceedings before the Court, however we are carefully reviewing the claims ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PayPal Australia taking ASIC legal action 'very seriously'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Now the former Qantas boss has departed the airline, questions are now turning to whether Alan Joyce will receive his widely reported "golden handshake" payout, given the the scandals the airline has been engulfed with in the past week or so. It certainly appears to be a live possibility on the boardroom table, with Qantas chair Richard Goyder yesterday telling The Australian that there were provisions for clawbacks in its remuneration report. With the board under mounting pressure, just how likely is that to happen? And how much is Joyce set to walk away with as he retires from Qantas? I've taken a look into that very question — you can read the answers (and get well versed in how Qantas pays its executives and its corporate structure at the same time) below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could Qantas take back Alan Joyce's payout?

featuredLink.title: Alan Joyce leaves Qantas with millions in the bank, but his final scandal as CEO has slashed his last payout

title.children: How much are short-term rentals really impacting Australia's housing crisis?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
By political reporter Tom Lowrey Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is expected to sit down with China's Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of the ASEAN summit in Jakarta this morning, in what would be the highest-level meeting between the two countries this year. Premier Li is China's second-highest-ranking official after President Xi Jinping, who has opted not to attend a series of global summits underway this week. There had been hopes Albanese might meet President Xi at the G20 leader's summit in Delhi this weekend, re-creating a significant meeting of the two leaders at last year's G20 summit in Bali. But with that no longer an option, it is now expected the PM will meet Premier Li instead. It's anticipated the two leaders would meet ahead of the East Asia Summit, which brings together South-East Asian leaders with leaders of countries like Australia, Japan, China, Russia and the USA. While diplomatic and trade relations between Australia and China have improved substantially in recent months, there are some substantial issues that might be raised. Trade barriers remain in place on Australian wine exports, and ministers have spoken out in recent months calling for their removal. Two Australians also remain detained in Beijing —
journalist Cheng Lei, and writer Dr Yang Hengjun. The government has openly called for both Australians to be reunited with their families, and Foreign Minister Penny Wong yesterday told the ABC that officials were continuing that pressure. "We are deeply concerned about Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang, as are so many Australians," she said. "And we have continued to raise with our counterparts at every level the desire of Australia to see both Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang reunited with their families. "We'll continue to make those representations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM expected to meet China's second-highest-ranking official in Indonesia

desire of Australia to see both Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang reunited with their families.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: YEAH. THE. GIRLS. Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso have been nominated for 2022-23 Women's Ballon d'or, which is awarded to the best female footballer in 2023. It's the first time two Australians have reached the shortlist for football's most prestigious individual award. Matildas captain and Chelsea star Kerr has been nominated every year since the Women's Ballon d'or was introduced in 2018, while it's Raso's first nomination. Spain and Barcelona midfielder Aitana Bonmati is the favourite, having recently claimed the UEFA Player of the Year award ahead of Kerr.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso nominated for Women's Ballon d'or

children.content: YEAH. THE. GIRLS.

props.alt: Hayley jumps on Sam's back as they celebrate.

children.content: Hayley Raso and Sam Kerr.
(Getty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rolling Stones are returning with their first original album in 18 years. The band launched their 24th studio album Hackney Diamonds at a theatre in east London before unveiling the music video to the single Angry, starring actress Sydney Sweeney. This will be the Stones' first album without long-time drummer Charlie Watts who died in 2021. The band also hinted fans can expect collaborations with Stevie Wonder and Lady Gaga – when the full album's released on October 20.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rolling Stones announce release date for new album, unveil lead single

props.alt: The three remaining band members smile on stage.

children.content: Ronnie Wood, Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards.
(Scott Garfitt/Invision/AP)
